"Ok, kiddo," you say to the elf. "What are you called?"
"Before bein' turned inta dis dumb ting? Madda. I's a orc afore dat mustachy guy..."
"I know, I know... We need to get to the Empire of Light. That's where the wizards are. They'll help you.
"Oh, tanku tanku tanku!"
You begin your journey with Madda the orc. He's very sweet and well mannered, as orcs go. Some creatures are more evil than they seem, but some are nicer. You wonder if he's trying to pull something.
1121222111.title: Madda

choices: Take the risk and set up camp with the orc here
Keep traveling as long as you can with Madda
11212221112.content:
You decide that you're probably just being paranoid, but you don't speak to the orc too much as you continue, anyway. However, he DOES speak to you. He sure has a lot to talk about, yet somehow he seems to avoid talking much about himself. You try your best to look like you're listening (even though half the time you can barely understand what he's saying).
As the night continues to get darker, your orbs seems to shed less light. You must decide how much longer you wish to go. Would it be safe to camp with Madda the orc? He does seem nice enough, but that paranoia in the back of your head keeps resurfacing.
11212221112.title: Or maybe you're just paranoid

112122211121.content:
"Madda," you interrupt the creature's ramblings, "my orb is growing dim and I think it is best we stop for the night. How do you feel about that?"

"Yesz, we canz stop for a rest. Would youz like me to gatherz woodz for a fire?"

"Sure, Madda, thanks for helping," you respond as you clear a place for the fire and gather stones.

Your stomach rumbles and complains for skipping dinner. It will be too late now for food, however. Madda seems to be taking his sweet time gathering wood for the fire. You are getting drowsy waiting for him. Sitting against a tree, you struggle to hold your eyes open and finally give in to sleep.

Meanwhile, Madda has found some friends and leads them straight to you.

"Thank you, Madda, you have done well. Here is your reward," the dark figure smirks as he hands the creature a purse of coins. Madda scampers off with his prize as the dark figure approaches and silently raises his sword. It comes down swiftly into your chest. Your eyes open long enough to see a dark shadow looming over you before your life slips away. Clearly, you should have been more careful who you trust.

112122211122.content: Even though Madda has not gotten up to any mischief as of yet, you dare not sleep in his presence. After all, his appearance may have changed, but his is still an orc on the inside, and from your knowledge they cannot be trusted. Also, since when do orcs travel alone? It is with this last thought that you realize you hear footsteps -- many footsteps behind you. Swinging around, your orb illuminates a group of large orcs, drooling with hunger, weapons towards you. With no time to react, spears and arrows pummel your body, giving you no chance at life. In the end, you are the main course. Be careful who you keep company with!

You turn around back to the forest and walk hurriedly into it. You are know in close sight of the swamp. You feel as if somethings watching you. Shrugging it of you try to figure out what to do. You know that you need to go north but you are still by the swamp. If you continue heading west you may never get to where you need to go. Or you could go through the swamp.
Knowing that in the west is only what seems to be a vast desert and hardly a chance of survival. The swamp with unknown inhabitants you may have a better chance in the desert but you would not make it to the Empire of Lights.
1121222112.title: You feel sorry for him, but you've gotta he...

choices: Continue on your journey. You don't know how much time you have!
Catch the rainbow carp. You want to fight with a God!
11212221121.content: As you approach the edge of the marsh, you scold yourself: If I were to cross this blasted dammed up river anyway, why couldn't I have done it back there? But there is no time for that now. Mentally preparing yourself, you take a step in. Squelch. The sound of your good boots sinking into the icky mud makes you want to scream. And yet... The water doesn't look as bad as it did when you were standing on the bank. You take another step. The water looks even clearer, but you are starting to feel sicker. At each step, the water gets clearer, cleaner, while you feel more and more nauseous. Finally, you reach the other side. You would be ecstatic, if you didn't feel so sick. And now the water is crystal clear! You crawl up the shore. Strangely, about three yards from the bank of the river, you find a large hole. Not a bottomless hole, it is only about 20 feet deep. So you lean over it and puke. And you keep puking and puking until the hole is full. You feel so grossed out. Then you realize... The vomit in the hole is all the filth from the water. You recognize the stench and strange color. And when you look again, the hole has disappeared. Was it your imagination...? You head over to the river and look in. It is deeper than before, you realize, and the water is the cleanest you've ever seen. Now it is filled with fish, crabs, lobsters... All sorts of water-animals. You are so thirsty, that you take a handful of the water and take a sip. You feel great! No, not just great, immortal, almost! Then you see a pack of dark shapes moving towards you through the water. You step away from the shore, but there pop up the heads and torsos of beautiful women! You gasp, looking at their tails. Mermaids! A brunette, obviously the leader, moves to the front of the pack. "Hello, human. We would like to thank you for the power of light. You sucked up all the muck from here, and the water has broken the dams! We are free once again!" "What about the forest? Won't it just put the dams back up?" "No, it takes a lot of work to do that, and, after they saw the damage they did to their precious river, they've decided it's not worth the trouble. "Oh," you say. "So you were living in that filthy water all along?" The brunette looks thoughtful, then nods. "Yes, we have been. Trapped under layers and layers of poisonous muck. You must be a powerful human, to do that!" "Thank you," you say, blushing at her compliment. "And the water is magical! It gives you super-human strength! And if you eat a lobster from this water, it gives you the power to speak to nature and animals. And if you catch a crab and eat it, you can turn into a mermaid when you go into the water. If you catch a shrimp and eat it, you can fly. And if you catch the rainbow carp and eat it... You have the power to control the powerful God, Pyui! But not for long. Here you are!" One of the mermaids fills a canteen full of the water. You gulp it down, you are so thirsty, and then refill it. Another mermaid grabs a crab and kills it, giving you a bite of its flesh. Another mermaid grabs and kills a lobster, giving you a bite of its flesh. Another mermaid feeds you a shrimp. You thank them as you feel yourself growing stronger, growing a bond with nature, having the power to become a mermaid, and sprouting large, beautiful, glimmering silver wings. You tuck them in. "Now, some gifts to show you our gratitude," said the brunette, One mermaid gives you leather arrow pouch filled with silver tipped arrows, along with a lovely bow. You sling them over your shoulders. Another mermaid gives you backpack that fits around your wings. Another mermaid gives you new boots, even finer than the ones you lost in the mud. Another mermaid presents you with a gleaming sword, and another presents you with gold. You put the sword into the hilt on your belt and gold in you backpack. Your hands blaze with light for a moment and the faerie cries out, momentarily blinded. You take a small jar from your pouch and quickly snatch the faerie out of the air and tightly close the lid.

"So, what is your name, faerie?" you ask it.

"Let me out! Let me out!" she pounds on the glass with her tiny fists.

"I'm sorry, but I just want to speak with you, and I was afraid you'd fly away." you say gently.

"Just don't blind me..." she says in a high voice.

"Fine. What is your name?" you ask again.

"My name is Thita." she sobs sorrowfully.

"Why does my light hurt your eyes? Aren't faeries aligned with good as well?" you walk over to a tree and lean against it.

Thita does not answer for a moment and struggles before she speaks. "I used to be aligned with light. But there are some... changes... in this realm. I changed sides..."

"So you're an evil faerie?" you say and raise an eyebrow.

"What does he want you for?" you ask and shift the small jar as the wind rustles your hair in a soft breeze.

The little faerie takes this in, then looks at you optimistically. "Let me go with you." She practically begs. "I've always wanted to see outside the forest but am unable to go on my own. I promise I won't be a bother, My magic might even be of use to you and it won't take all that long for my eyes to adjust to the light. Oh please let me go. I used to ask all the humans that went by but not one said yes and I finally gave up of ever leaving this place, but you're different, you have to be." "I don't believe you!" you shout. You don't trust goblins, and you never will.
"No! I'm... too weak... must die..." he mutters some uncomprehending words and his eyes slowly shut. You gasp at what you have done.
"I've killed this goblin!" you are amazed, and you feel a bit sorry for the goblin, but he asked for it, didn't he?
You continue walking around, though you're really walking in circles. Suddenly, there is a large group of goblins surrounding you.
"You killed Meldorv!" they shout angrily. You try to blind them with your light and orb, but they don't budge.
"Only he was afraid of light, you silly human! We are not scaredy-cats like he is!" the goblins chant. More goblins surround you. Some grasp your legs, arms, hands, feet, and hair. They all pinch and punch and kick at you, and you are helpless with your light. They grin, but after half an hour one of them announces, "I'm hungry! Let's eat this little human!"
"Please don't eat me, sweet goblins! I wouldn't do that to you, would I?" you say, looking small and frightened.
"Yes, you did that to Meldorv!" and they start chanting a song, "The human is the enemy, we are small and kind, the human kills and wishes for power, we are cute and cuddly!" they sing rudely and off-key, and their voice is horrible.
Suddenly, you remember an old story you heard, about a boy who was captured by goblins, but escaped by outwitting them. You think fast.
"Oh, but... wouldn't you like me to entertain you first? And, I have many treasures inside here..." you say. The goblins look suspicious but curious, too. One of them shouts, "Sure!"
You rack your brains for something to tell them. Then, you start to tell a story. "Once there was a little girl. Her name was... Jenny. And she was very pretty, with pretty blond hair and blue eyes." the goblins look angry suddenly. One of them asks, "Is she a human?"
"Um, no. She was a goblin, too. And her hair was... green. So were her eyes. One day, she was exploring a small cave. Jenny found a butterfly."
"Is it a fly made out of butter?" the goblin asks stupidly.
"Yes, and it was so delicious!" you decide to lie to them. "Jenny ate the butter-fly, but inside her stomach, the butterfly flew around, and it was sad because the butterfly was very pretty." the goblins laugh. One of them starts to get tired, and he slowly falls asleep. A few others do too.
After a few hours, you are dancing and singing a nursery rhyme. Quite a few goblins are asleep, as only two goblins are still staring at you and yawning, too. They get drowsy and slowly fall asleep. You grin and pump your fist in the air.
"Yes!" you say. You tip-toe past the goblins, skipping all the way. You find a small cave and wonder what to do with it.

Beware of the one called Centurin, for his power is great and he seeks to destroy you."

"Before you go great wizard, I implore you, please tell me more of my mission."

"Alright, but quickly," he says as he draws closer to you.
Continuing in a low voice he shares some more information.
"A great conflict is brewing between the forces of good, which are to the North and South and the forces of evil which are to the East and West. This forest has always been considered neutral ground, and for this moment still is. But soon it will be a bloody battleground."
The wizard pauses with a sorrowful look in his eye, as if he is seeing the future.
"You have been brought here alone and in secret, chosen because of your exceptional abilities - your sharp mind, able body, and strong personality. The fate of the forest and this realm will rest in your hands, and the hands of others just like yourself, who have also been chosen."

"What is causing the conflict?" you ask, still confused.

"I don't have time to go into this now. You will learn as you travel. Be careful who you befriend in this forest. Some can give you invaluable insight and help, and others live only to decieve and destroy you," the wizard informs.

The wizard, in a dark cloud of smoke, disappears from sight, leaving you alone in the forest.
You can hear his voice in the wind saying, "You need to journey to the Dark Castle, far to the West. There you will gain perfection in your new craft and further direction."

1221212.content:
The old lady yelps in surprise and shock upon seeing a person collapsed on her kitchen floor. She runs to you, checking for pulse and instantly feeling that your body is warm. She can tell you are alive and she rushes to get a cool damp cloth to put on your forehead. You groggily "awaken", pretending to be dazed and confused.

"What happened? Where am I?" you ask softly.

"You are in my home, Dear, but I don't know anything else as I just walked in and found you on the floor. My name is Winifred Gales."

Winifred helps you sit up and fetches you a glass of water, waiting while you recover.

"Are you a traveler, Dear?" asks Winifred.

"Yes, I am just passing through. I think I was being chased, but I'm not sure by whom. I haven't eaten all day. Perhaps that and the anxiety of being chased is what caused me to faint. I'm sorry to intrude. I will be on my way."

"Oh, nonsense," replied Winifred. "Stay a while and have some food. I've got plenty here. Take some time to gain your strength before you are off. There have been strange goings ons in these parts lately."

"Oh? Tell me more," you implore.

"Well, more and more dark creatures are in the forest and the air has become increasingly heavy and damp. There have been more and more travelers as well - different sorts of people and elves, going this way and that. They tell me a war is brewing, but I don't know much more than that. I do know that I'm not sleeping as well at night, now. I hear strange noises in the night that send tremors down my spine."

You listen intently, gleaning as much information as you can while you help yourself to the food.

"What do you think the noises are?"

"I'm not certain, but I think they are orcs - terrible, ugly creatures meant for evil. Sometimes I hear screeches, like the sounds of giant hawks screaming. And then, unmistakably, I hear the voices of people; sometimes talking, sometimes yelling, and at worst, screaming, which startles me so badly my heart pains me. I have put bolts on my doors for the night, although I hardly think it would stop anyone who really wanted to get in."

Your eyebrows raise. This place did not sound very pleasant at night, that is for sure.

"Have you thought about leaving the area, Winifred? Is there a safer place you could go?"

Winifred thought for a moment. "I haven't considered leaving, but if this place becomes a battleground, I feel it might be wise. I'm not sure where I would go, however. Is there really any place safe when there is a war on?"

You nod in understanding as you chew on a chicken leg.

"And where are you travelling to, my Dear?"

Swallowing your chicken you reply, "the Dark Castle. Do you know of it?"

Winifred's eyebrows raised, "The Dark Castle? Oh, yes, I have heard of it. It stands to the far west. Are you sure you want to go there?"

"Yes, why do you ask?"

"It's just that you seem like a nice person. I can't imagine what business you would have there. It's not a pleasant place, at least not that I've heard. I haven't been there myself. I know it's not my business, but why are you going there?"

You aren't sure how much information you should give. You don't really know Winifred. She seems innocent enough, but who could tell for sure at this early stage?

Winifred pours two cups of tea and sips the one closest to her. "I'm not asleep, so it must be real. Who told you to go to the castle?"

"A wizard," you reply in disbelief at what you are saying. "One minute I'm home, the next I'm in a forest being told I'm going to be a part of saving the world. It doesn't make any sense to me, honestly."

Winifred has been eyeing your brooch and cloak while you speak. "Well, you can rest here for the night if you would like. I have a spare bedroom you should feel comfortable in. I shudder to think of you out there unsheltered."

"Thank you, that is a kind offer," you reply with a smile.

You finish your meal and tea and you and Winifred retire by the warm fire in the next room. Winifred seems kind enough and the sun is beginning to get low in the sky. A bead of sweat started running down from her head to her cheek. Picking up the dagger in one hand, she slipped the hood of her cloak on. She immediately became invisible.

"Your cloak will do you no good," a man's voice echoed gently in the air all around her. "For we can see you."

"Who are you? What do you want?" she asked looking all around her to see from which direction the man was speaking.

"I am called Samada, General of the Woodland Elves. We mean you no harm, as long as you bring no harm to the Woodlands."

"Show yourselves," she asked as she removed the hood of her cloak. What use was it if they could see her already.

"Put down your weapon, and we shall make ourselves known unto you," Samada requested.

She sheathed her dagger on the side of her right forearm. It was small and easily accessible from there. "I am Beth. I am not sure how I got her or even where I have come from."

Samada, along with twenty different elves, cam out of the wood line to reveal themselves to her. They were tall, muscular men with pointed ears. All of them carried a bow, two daggers, a sword made of a metal Beth had never seen before, and long emerald green robes. Although the elves had different color hair of many different lengths, they all had a violet purple eyes, and a crystal that illuminated hanging around their necks.

"My men and I are scouts for His Majesty Seth Kildonan, King of the Woodland Elves. We have been watching you for several hours, to see if you were a friend or foe."

"Believe me, I'm not here to cause any harm to anyone," Beth said dusting off her knees.

"Come with us, so we may eat and drink. The Woodland has many foes, who come out in the coldness of night. Their eyes are sharp and their hearing is keen. Follow me," Samada said leading her away from the place in which she woke.

Samada led Beth and his men south. The elves were extremely careful not to break any of the vines or shrubs in the lush forest. They simply moved a branch here and there, then quietly moved on around the obstacle. Beth followed them, keeping her eyes open for anything else strange or foreign.

They passed by a waterfall that ran down one of the highest peaks Beth had ever seen. It had willow trees lining its creek, ferns all around, and huckleberry bushes filled with the tasty pinkish red berries. Beth smiled and drank the beauty in. If this was a dream, she wished she could build a house right here and live the rest of her days.

"Come. We must not linger while danger is so close," Samada said passing Beth by. Beth ran to catch up with him.

"What do you mean?" she asked out of breath.

"You are a strange warrior. Do you not know when you are being tracked?" Samada questioned cautiously.

"To tell you the truth, I am no warrior. I don't know how to use this sword or bow. I did take self defense class once, so I know how to use the knife. As for the other items, i don't have a clue," beth shrugged.

"Stay close then. There is no time to teach you here. Once we get to the Village of Dan'ne, I will show you." Samada turned and whispered, "Tha'mere dalimorah. Pashinglah."

With those words the elves picked up the pace, and Beth found herself in almost a dead sprint. "We must hurry. Gi'lorhim and his men are close. They must not catch up with us."

"Who is 'Gi'lorhim'?" Beth panted almost out of breath.

"He is a goblin spy. A slimy filthy creature who has been kidnapping our women and children. He thinks we will tell him were the jewel of the Empire of Light is, if they torment our kin," Samada answered.

The elves pressed onward for several hours, only stopping for water and to let Beth rest her feet for a few minutes.

Soon they reached the edge of the Woodlands. Samada crawled on his stomach out into the meadow on a hill that over looked the Village of Dan'ne Dale. "Mattithya," he whispered. Beth looked over her shoulder to see one of the elves pass by her and started crawling like Samada once he got to the meadow. The two men talked for a few moments before the one Samada called 'Mattithya' crawled back to the Woodland edge and then ran back the the end of the group.

Samada came back to the group also, after a few minutes. "We will go in fours down to the village. I do not detect danger, but this way, if there is any danger, we will not all be caught up in an ambush."

Beth nodded. She picked up her pack of arrows, and put it on her back, leaving her hands free to only carry the bow. Samada, Beth, and two other elves who she did not know the names to, headed to the village first.

They didn't walk with curiously and speed, like they did in the woodlands. They now walked with assurance, wisdom, and pride.

The village was an array of village of woodland elves, moving about the village purchasing goods of all kinds. The children were playing with little bugs, that appeared to be fireflies.

"Those are Wildflowere Pixies. They are small, but they carry the pollen of the wildflowers, which produce an amazingly strong healing power. Their wings produce a sound of music that calms the soul. They love to be around children. They like their energy," Samada explained.

"I noticed some of your arrows are broken. I can take you to F'lorin. He is amazing at fixing things. But, if you wish I can take you to the home of my father, where you can eat and rest. There is much to do tomorrow."
122122.title: Friend or Foe? (F)

choices: Join Samada, and look at the map later?
Take the map, and find your own way to the castle?
1221222.content:
"Although I would like to find out the meaning of the two different arrows and get them repaired, I am awful hungry. And, a bed sure does sound good.," Beth said as she wiped the sweat from her brow.

Samada smiled at her. "You are a strange human, Beth. I have never seen one that spoke the way you do, or acted the way you do. What tribe are you from?" he asked walking her down the lane. Children were running bout trying to catch the pixies.

Beth laughed at what Samada had said. She waited to see if he really wanted to know what tribe she was from. when he looked at her with the question still on his face, she knew it wasn't a joke. "I don't come from any tribe. I was born and raised in Winnipeg, Canada. We have people called 'Native Americans', who consist of hundreds of tribes, but I am not a Native American."

Samada looked awstruck. "You mean you had no mother or father who raised you? You are an orphan?"

Beth smiled and shook her head. She didn't quite know how to explain it. She never really had to think about things like this back before the white wizard spoke to her. "No. I had a mother and a father, who are probably worried sick about me by now," she thought. "Where I come from our 'tribes' are called 'families'. My family name is Lavallee."

"Beth of the La...vallee," Samada parroted. Samada smiled and looked at Beth approvingly. "You have a beautiful tribe name. My tribal name is the Hawkeye Tribe. We have been the leaders of the Elf Warriors for ten centuries. It is a great honour to serve the king, and the spirits of the Woodlands."

"I feel blessed to have met you Samada," Beth said putting out her hand to him.

He looked at her soft hands for a moment. They were not course or rough, like the ones of the women he knew, from hard labor. They were smooth, and soft. It was then he noticed her complexion. Her skin was white, and smooth. Her cheeks were pink, like the clouds at sunset. Her eyes were as blue as the Great River. She looked like an angel.

He stretched out his hand to hers and gave it a shake. "I am glad it was I who had found you first my lady. Gi'lorhim has been wondering in our forest for weeks, waiting for us to drop our guard."

Samada led her to an enchanting home, made of (what looked to her) riverbed rocks. The front of the home was gardened in an array of strange,yet beautiful, flowers. Humming birds flew all around, drinking of the sweet nectar of the honeysuckle bushes.

"This is the home of my father, Rychin. It will be safe for you," Samada encouraged as he opened the thick redwood doors.

"Sam! Sam! You are home!" two little elf girls with long curly brown hair exclaimed, jumping up and down with excitement in their eyes. "Mother, mother," the shouted as they took off running to another room down the marble hall.

"Those are my sisters. Iris is the taller one. The little one is Lily. They get rather excited at times, but one can't help but fall in love with them," he smiled.

Beth smiled at the little elf girls. They reminded her of her sister, who at this moment would be asking mother for just one more glass of water before she 'really' went to sleep. "They're lovely Samada. They remind me of..." she couldn't finish. She hadn't realized how home sick she really was, and to think that her mission had only just begun; according to the white wizard.

Samada raised Beth's chin with his strong hand, so her gaze met his. She felt so alone. "Remind's you of what Beth of the Lavallee's?"

Beth felt a lump in her throat. A tear ran down her pink cheeks. She hadn't realized the caring or wisdom she shown through the pupils of Samada's violet purple eyes. "Of home," she whispered.

"When you have partaken of food, and have rested your weary body, we shall talk about why you are here, and try to figure out your destiny. The wisdom of the Woodlands and the peace of the Great River will explain things more clearly to us," Samada comforted.

Beth smiled as her attention was drawn from Samada to the elderly woman who was heading this way, with Iris and Lily skipping next to her.

"See, mother? See? Sam is back, jest like he promised!" little Iris exclaimed tugging on her mother's hand.

"Mother, I have returned home weary of travel, and hungered. May I seek refuge in the house of my father for my self and a weary traveler that the White Wizard placed in the Woodlands for my safe keeping?" he asked his mother. He took the old woman elf's hand and kissed it gently and then lowered himself to one knee, awaiting her approval.

"Samada, my dear son. You are always welcome to say here, after your journey," she smiled at her son, kissing him on his forehead. She then looked at Beth and took Beth's hands into hers. Beth felt warmth, love, comfort, and peace serging through her hands that were being held; piercing the utter most parts of her body.

"Who am I to question the White Wizard. If in your path this lady of the woods has been place, then in this place shall she find comfort for her soul, food for her stomach, and a bed to rest. Come my lady. Lay down your burdens and be comforted in the house of Rychin, my husband. I am Dawn from the house for Flor'rin," She smiled leading Beth to a place where she was helped out of the satchel of arrows.

Samada took off his weapons, except his dagger that was strapped to the inner left ankle. Beth followed suet and left everything in the closet of the great hall, except the dagger strapped to her forearm.

Beth looked all around her as she was led into what looked like a great reception room. It had an oak dinning table that stretched the full length of the vast room. The windows, that looked like they were made of pure crystal, were treated with pastel shear fabric that looked as thin as lacy paper as the wind blew gently against them. It looked stunning. In each corner of the ceiling, an angel statue was posted sitting in prayer, guarding the people within its boundaries.

Dawn pointed to the table for them to sit, as she went to the great kitchen to prepare the feast. Samada pulled out a chair for Beth and then chose to sit opposite her. Iris and Lily sat on either side of their big brother.

Iris looked at the kitchen doors to see if her mother was listening. "Did you fight any...goblins, Sam?" she whispered using her tiny right hand to cover the movement of her lips, so anyone who wasn't close would know what she had been asking.

"Not today, little one," Sam smiled.

Iris sat back in her chair and pouted with her arms crossed. Then she sat straight up and asked, "Can you tell Lily and me a story of one of the times you did?"

"NO!" Lilly shook her head, causing her little curls to swing back and forth. "You know those stories give me bad sleeps! Sam, please don't tell one of those, please?" Lily begged pulling on the sleeve of his emerald robe. "Tell us the one of the Pixie Princess. The one who gave you that shiny globe."

Samada looked into Beth's eyes, which were gleaming in laughter. Beth was enjoying the girls, as well as the safety of the grand house. "How about when you girls go to bed? I'll tuck you in and tell you a pixie story then."

"Yeah!" the girls shouted in unison, clapping their hands.

At that moment, an elderly looking elf came into the dinning hall. "Father!" the girls shouted as they got up and ran to him

The elderly elf held out his hand to calm them down. The girls stop running in mid stride. the both regained their composure and stood in front of their father with their heads bowed.

"Lady elves must move with grace, so they do not fall and hurt themselves. I love my little ladies, and do not want to see their snowy white skin bruised like a bunch of dwarfs playing in the dry river beds," he reproached with a gentle smile.

"We didn't mean to father," Iris apologized.

Lily looked at her big sister and then at her father. "Can I have a huggy love and a kissy smack now father?"

Beth and Samada covered their grinning face with thier hands and waited to see what the old man would do. He opened his arms, and the girls came to him with their arms wide open. They kissed their father on both his cheeks and then let go of the embrace.

Samada stood and took the hand that his father offered him, and gave it a hearty shake as he too kissed both cheeks of his father. "It does my eyes good to see you in good spirits father."

"Its good to have you safe in my house once more, my dear son," he smiled. His attention then turned to Beth, who was enjoying the love that was so publicly shown. Beth wondered if she could remember the last time she had embraced her father and told him how much she appreciated
him and her mother. She was embarrassed to think it had been so long.

"I see my house has welcomed a pedal from the apple blossoms of the Woodlands," he smiled as he offered his hand to Beth. Beth stood and gave him her hand. He brought it to his lips and kissed the back of her hand.

"This is Beth of the Lavallee tribe. She has been sent by the White Wizard," Samada said. "Beth, this is my father, Rychin from the house of Anigoran."

"An honor to be invited to your home sir," Beth smiled.

"Sit, sit. Your journey has been long, and your burden was heavy. Enjoy the feast in which my house has prepared, for we have much to discus before our eyes can rest," Rychin announced to his guest and son.

"Can we stay up too father?" Iris asked.

"Little lady elves must have their sleep if they are to ever be as pretty as the Pegasuses, which fly through the air," their father smiled.

"Yes, father," the girls echoed.

At that moment, Dawn came out of the kitchen with a platter of corn on the cob, and a large crystal bowel of tossed greens, and sat them on the table. She leaned over nd gave her husband a kiss on his forehead. "I'm glad you made it for supper my dear husband."

"I couldn't be late for your apple cobler dear," Rychin grinned.

Beth waved her hand at him, smiling as she went back into the kitchen. She returned carrying a tray that had a golden roasted turkey. She sat it down in the middle of the table where they were sitting and then sat between her husband and Beth.

Rychin stood and the rest of the family held hands. Dawn and Samada took Beths hands as Rychin began to speak. "To the fields of harvest, our house gives thanks. For it is your soil that has grown the harvest in which we now partake. To the bird of the forest, we say thanks. For, it is because of your sacrifice that we can partake of your meat to fill out bodies. May your spirit take flight once more to the flok that awaits for you in the heavens."

Rychin then took a knife and cut the large bird, feeding Iris and Lily first, then Beth, Dawn, Samada, and himself last. The food was filling. Beth couldn't remember the last time she had the oppertunity to sit at a dinner table and eat among those who were family. Not even her own.

After a helping of thier mothers delicous apple cobbler, Lilly and Iris were shoo'ed off to bed. "But, you promised to tell me a story about the Pixie Princess Sam," Lily's little lips quivered.

Samada knelt down to his little sister and dried her tear with his thumb. He kissed her little pointy ears and her nose. "You don't want to let the pixies fly away, because you scared them with your crying now would you?" he asked holding her little head in his strong hands.

She shook her head no, looking all around with her eyes to see if she really scared the pixies away. "Then no more tears," Samada ordered with a grin. Lily nodded with a smile.

"Father had need of me for a few moments. As soon as I tarry with father, I will come to you straight away and I shall tell you all I know of the Pixy Princess Alhora."

"Promise?" she sniffed.

"I give you my word as a General," he said standing up and saluting her.

She covered her mouth with her tiny hands and giggled. "I can't wait!" Lily then turned to Beth and waved good-bye, in which Beth returned the wave with a smile.

Samada turned to face Beth once Lily was gone from the hall. "Father carries news of the Dark Castle."

"The Dark Cas...," Beth muttered. "That's where I have been told to go by the White Wizard! Has your father just come from there? Can he help me get there?"

Samada looked at her with his eyes bulging, "Are you mad? To go to the Dark Castle alone is a death wish, and almost impossible. If one makes it past the goblins and orcs after crossing the haunts of the Ghost River, one still has to navigate the Great River!

"The Great River can lead one to one of the only safe places one can use for rest...the house of the wise elves of the River of Dan. But, its pointless, because no one has been able to navigate that river with any success in over a hundred years."

"Itsn't there another path we may take?" Beth asked.

Samada shook his head, "The terrain might be better , but there are creatures there that are more terrifying than orcs or goblins. Many have gone before. The ones who HAVE made it back were made mad. Some of those places have creatures that even the Wise Council of the Elves don't even know about."

"There must be a way!" Beth pleaded holding her head in her hands. "Why would I be sent there, if there was no way to get there?"

Samada took Beth by the arms and hugged her, to comfort her. "I have a map, and I've been studying the terrain since I was but a lad, and have found no SAFE way of entering."

Beth looked up at him for a moment in thought. "May I see it?"

"Sure," Samada said. He led her back to the great hall and took the map out of his satchel. He opened the brown rice paper scroll on an endtable nearby.

"See, this is the Empire of Light to our north. It is the home of the Great Wizards of Najah, The Land of the Empire. The white wizard resides there, and takes council within.

"To the south, is the Great River, and the Forks of Dan. The wisest of elves abide in the deep beautiful forests, except the walls of the river are too steep to walk and the river rages between.

"We are here," he pointed on the map. "But, we are surrounded by caves, which are homes to those filthy little goblins. And, below them are the Orcs and Elves who have turned their powers over to Lord of Darkness. They are evil, cunning, and can take on many different forms."

Samada liffted his illuminating crystal that was hanging around his neck. "When a dark elf is around, our crystals illuminate red. When in the presence of the wise elf they illuminate green. When in the presence of kin they..."

"They turn purple," Beth finished. Samada nodded.

"To the west, over here," Samada marked on the map, "this is the Ghost River. Many evil things abide here. Its a vast array of mines, graves, and shafts. All are patrolled by goblins and dwarfs, who want nothing but gold and materialistic pleasures. They care nothing for life or the welfare of others.

"The forests that surround the Dark Castle often end without warning. Many of friends have met their fate on those cliffs," he said walking away from the map.

Beth took the map and looked at it harder. There must be some way to get to the Dark Castle.

"Samada! Come, join me in drink and in thought my son," Rychin called down the hall after him. "Bring your guest, if the lass wishes to partake in word."

"Would you join me in conversation with my father Beth?"
1221222.title: There Must Be A Way! (F)

choices: Find F'lorin to fix the arrows first?
Train with Samada, so you can use your majical powers?
12212221.content:
Beth smiled at Samada as she folded the map and stuck it into her coat pocket. Samada led her into a different part of the house. Candles flickered against the darkness, and a fire in the brick fireplace warmed the coolness in the air.

"Sit my son," Rychin jestered to an over stuffed couch opposite him. Samada led Beth to the couch, and he and she sat.

Rychin sat looking into the fire, while puffing on his corn cob pipe. smoke trickled our his lips and nose as he sat in thought. Beth felt a chill runup her spine, causeing the hairs on her neck to stand up. She tugged her coat snuggly around herself, as she too started gazing into the flames of the fire.

"What do you see, father?" Samada asked.

"I see darkness...and sufferung. The hand of Zarenian grows powerful," Rychin puffed on his pipe some more. "Ones who the Woodland Elves once called allies and friends now betray us. We will no longer be safe in this dark hour."

Rychin took a pouch from his robes and opened it. Inside was what looked like teal grains of sand. Rychin took but a pinch, and tossed it into the flames of the fire. The fire raged hot and a puff of smoke boomed out with a flash. Beth jumped back at the unforseen explosion, however Samada and Rychin sat still.

"There will be no rest for the Woodland Elves, for war is imminate. The eyes of the Elves of the Great Council will be callused. The Humans' faith is waivering. The Orcs seek to gain a treaty with the Dark Elves.

"Goblins rage war with the Dwarfs, who have an unforseen future. Their love of materialisic goods may overtake them, if they are not careful." Rychin turned to Beth and looked deep into her eyes. Beth wanted to turn away, but her spirit wouldn't allow it. It was like she was being drawn into the mind of Rychin.

"You, my lady, hold the key to our world. Our future, as the future of the Mystic Forest, lays in your hands. Your paath has been presented before you, yet you are unsure. Trust no one, for they trust you not. They arrows in which you have touched, carry two faits. Choose wisely, and you will be a stepp closer in saving us all. Choose in haste, and quickly will we fall from the top of the mountian."

Beth took a big gulp. She had never been trusted to do a thing in her life! Who in the world was she supose to save an entire world? She looked at Samada, who was sitting with his eyes closed, drinking in the words his father was prophesying.

Rychin took Beth's hands into his old ones, "Follow the wind, which carries the spirit of our ancestors, for they will lead you in the right path. Do not trust your own eyes, but my you be given the sight of the egale, for thier sight is keen and powerful. May you not be harmed, as you make your journey. The woodlands will give you the use of their beloved Pixie, Alorha. She will mend you if you should be harmed," he said as he got up and opened a window in the east part of the room.

Within seconds of the window being raised, Beth saw a the fluttering of tiny wings flying to her. She held out her hand as the little creature landed in her palm. It was a lady pixie. She stood an inch and a half tall. She had short blond hair that were in an array of ringlets with wildflowers pinned in different spots in her hair. She had green eyes that sparkeled, and didn't wear any shoes. The little pixie glowed as she bowed before Beth. Beth nodded back to her.

"I give you one last thing to help you on your quest...my son Samada. For he knows the forests and the land well. He has many friends in the animal world, as well and the mortal. Trust his path, for he will not lead you astray," Rychen said putting a hand on his son's shoulder.

"Now go. Rest, for you have many things ahead of you." With that, Rychin left the two in the sitting room alone.

Beth and Samada didn't speak a work. They both went to their own rooms to rest. Alorha followed Beth into her room, and found a basket of arranged flowers on a table near the bed. Alorha flew to the sunflower and laid down. Beth smiled at the little pixe as she too got into bed and rested. Tomorrow would be a big day. She had a few places she needed to go to before she would begin this ...quest. She just didn't know where to go first when she woke up.
12212221.title: A Gift from the Woodlands... (F)

choices: Go back to Smada's house, train for war, and share the Prophecy?
122122211.content:
Beth woke up not sure where she was. Warms rays of sunlight swept across her face. She rubbed her eyes, thinking that she was still in a dream. Once she sat up in the bed, she relised that this was no dream. Alorah was still sleeping peacfully, curlled up in the center of a sunflower. Beth smiled at the little pixie. She looked like a beautiful doll.

Beth walked over to a silver breakfast tray, possibly placed in her room by Samada's mother, and poured herself a fresh cup of hot coffee. She walked over to the window that over looked the veranda, and drank in the beauty of the little elvish town. She looked up and down the street, until something caught her eye. It was a sign that read "F'LORIN'S REPAIR and CURSE/MAGIC SPELL REMOVAL SHOP".

"My arrows!" she remembered. She buzzed around the bed, while taking off the nightgown Samada's mother lent her. When Beth opened the closet door, she saw clothes that weren't hers hanging in the place she had expected her own clothes to be hanging.

She didn't want to put on clothes that didn't belong to her without getting permission of the owner, but this was important. She needed to get to that shop! No time could be spared on formalities. She quickly got into the items that were neatly hung: light brown denim jeans, coral-color blouse that had long sleeves that she neatly rolled up to her elbows, a brown utility vest, black mid-calf boots, black leather belt with pouches of all shapes and sized fastened to it, and her pack of arrows.

She felt a little awkward wearing these items. She walked over to the vanity in the middle of the room and took a look at herself. Upon looking at the sight, she quickly turned around and put her hands over her eyes. She looking like one of Robin Hood's freakin' Merry Men!

She turned to grab the hair brush, making sure not to see her reflection, and brushed her hair so fast and hard that it hurt to the point of almost wincing. She set it down and rushed out of the house as quickly and quietly as possible. She didn't want to wake any of the hosts of the house up.

She turned down the alley headed for "F'Lorin's Shop". She watches all the elves going about their daily chores, which she would have never seen in her home town this early in the morning. She came to the conclusion that their were more people up at seven in the morning here than in anywhere in the States.

She smiled to all the elves that said good morning or smiled at her. It didn't take long for Beth to reach the shop. The outside looked like a normal adobe shop, decorated in an aray of hanging baskets of flowers. But that was nothing as compaired to the inside.

Beth entered the shop and stood in the middle of the grand shop looking at all the things that sat on the shelves, in cases, hanging from the ceiling (or better floating in the air), and stacked neatly on counter tops. There were green bottles of Skinner's Slow Seeping Slime (which was garunteed to get rid of any pesky critters that may try to get into your house through drains or faucets), boxes of Winee'Sha's Wonder Working Wands, baskets of garlic neclaces and roseries (which promised no vampire would come within miles of you or your home), Elvan and Elvan Q-tips (garunteed to get even the pointies ears clean), swords for all occasions (for social engagements or for battle front warfare), books on every subject one could fathem, and other articles that Beth couldn't read due to the elvish writing.

"May I help...," the shopkeeper stopped speaking as Beth turned and faced him. The old man stood with a hunched back, and ballanced himself with a rosewood cane. "Ah, yes! Miss Beth."

Beth's mouth dropped. "How did you know my name?" she questioned. She had never seen this man before this very moment.

"Chrystal never lies. She see's all, and knows all. For, she told me just last night that you would be seeing me this very moring. You have stumbled onto some items. Very curious items...curious indeed. Follow me, for we shall help you to decide your destiny better in the presents of Chrystal." The old Elf turned and headed into a dark room, lit with two candles, which was the only light source of the room.

Beth walked through the strings of beads that hung in the doorway and looked at her new surrounding. Beth didn't believe in any hocas pocas garbage, but then she never belied in pixies or elves either. what she did find odd in this place that was already odd to begin with, that F'Lorin and she were the only two persons in the room. "Where is Chrystal?" Beth asked.

At that moment F'Lorin removed the purple silk cover off of a clear ball. He sat down in a mohagany stained chair and pointed opposit him, suggesting to Beth to also take a seat.

"Beth, this is my dear friend Chrystal. She and I have been together since the begining of the Evlish time." He closed his eyes as Beth sat down. The only sound was that of her breathing and the faint of breathing noise F'Lorin made.

"Place the items on the table, but touch none of them with your bare hands." Sam did as instructed. The ball lit up with smoky blues, purples, and pinks. In acute flashes, Beth say Samada running as he shot arrows, Beth holding on for dear life on the edge of some rocky cliff with her feet dangling, other people and beasts unknown to her fighting, killing, beating, and crying.

F'Lorin took a piece of smoking sweat grass and encircled the ball with it. Almost immediatly the ball changed to colors of orange, yellow, and green. With this new change came the change of the scenes inside the ball. Samada with his hand on Beth's cheek. Beth riding horses across the country side with what looked like a small army of Elves, Scourcers, and Witches. It appeard victory was just one on some great balltefield.

"What does this mean? What are you showing me?" she asked as F'Lorin circled the ball one more time and the ball went into grey and white mist.

"It means be careful of the arrows you use. You have come across the arrows of fait. Choose one, and you have saved the lives of us all." F'Lorin stood up and placed the purple silk cloth back onto the ball.

"But if I don't chose the right one?" she pressed.

"Then this will be the last you or I see each other. The time of the Woodland Elves will come to a deadly end and life as you and I know it will no longer be."

"What bout the last grey and white smoke? What did that mean? does it mean anything at all?" she implored.

"It was the fog of uncertanty. You will come across an item that will either be of extreem god or extreem evil. Only you will be able to decide what to do with it and its powers. If you don't hold onto it, or someone else finds it before you, all is lost."
122122211.title: The Prophecy of F'Lorin (F)

choices: You cast the shadow down and back into your hands.
1222.content:
You notice your clothing has changed. You are wearing the colors of the darkest parts of the forest. A black, hooded cloak is draped over your shoulders, binded with a golden claps in the form of a serpent's head.
You feel more powerful inside and decide to experiment with the new power you feel. You cast the shadow that surrounds your hands onto the ground. The shadow begins to spin rapidly, rising upward, taking the shape of yourself.
You are now looking at a replica of yourself in shadow form.

122211.content:
You have no idea why you just told the shadow to do this, but he does.
The area he covers is dark, but you can still see. You want it to be night in this area, so you say, "Shadows darken into night, making children run in fright."
Suddenly the area the shadow was covering turn completely opaque. It was like a black hole - no vision possible at all, except for you of course. You have the ability to see in pure darkenss, because you hold the power.
122211.title: darkness falls (F)

choices: Say you are an agent of darkness.
1222111.content:
"Shadow deadening all the land, return swiftly to my hand." you murmur as the shadow contracts.

Confidently you turn west as the wizard had instructed. Your dark black cloak blends you into the shadows between the trees.

You come to a clearing with a grainy white obelisk in the center. You see a young man kneeling at the obelisk, his deft hands tracing a rune. Sensing your presence, he stands and whirls around.

You take in his appearance. He has fairly long blonde hair and the characteristic "dreamy" blue eyes. He wears silver armor and a graceful white cloak. He holds a large, flat shield with a griffon on its front as well as a long silver blade with an ivory handle. He looks at you questioningly, eyebrows scrunched.

He takes in your appearance. Your form is altered but equally as striking. He sees your shoulder-length, raven hair, your piercing green eyes, and your blood red lips. He takes in your sheer black cloak and golden snake clasps. He takes in the straps and bodice of your clothing halfway hidden by the cloak.

"Who are you?" He asks in a suspicious voice.
1222111.title: The Obelisk

choices: Agree to let Centurin accompany you West.
Refuse and use your cloak of invisibility to escape.
12221112.content:
You stare at him without speaking, unimpressed by his pompous purity.

He shifts his weight and then walks toward you. "Who are you, girl?"

You do not answer immediately but eventually say, "You are Centurin, are you not?"

The young man looks suprised while you wonder how you knew that this was the man the wizard had warned you about. Listening to the forest, you realize that you can hear the shadows of darkness telling you their secrets.

"I am Centurin, and I do not like the look of you. What do you want?" Centurin tilts back his head and studies you.

"I do not want anything with you." you sneer, "I am merely passing through here."

"A force of evil would have attacked me by now, so despite your looks, you must be aligned with good. If that is so, you would allow me to accompany you to your destination out of goodwill."
12221112.title: Centurin

122211121.content:
You suppress the feral smile that you're tempted to give him.

"Oh, yes, I'm goodness incarnate." you say, managing to mask the sarcasm. "I only pretend to be evil to weed out the weak and easily frightened, who I would not want to accompany me on my journey."

You are not sure if he believes you, but he nods slowly. "Then I shall join you in your journey, to wherever that may be."

If he gets annoying, you figure you can always kill him...but there is something about this young man that gives you the nagging feeling that he might be thinking exactly the same thing about you.
122211121.title: Agree to let Centurin accompany you West.

You realize that he knows who you are, and quickly toss your hood over your head. Being invisible isn't as nice as you thought it would be. Shadows that you can not command surround you, and you start to run away from them and Evil man. Soon you're out of sight and mind, not knowing where you're headed. Suddenly you run into something and you and your target fall to the ground, knocking your hood off. You wake up to someone humming. As you open your eyes you see the back of a man. His hair his a black as a crow's feathers. you can tell that he is a wanderer (someone who roams the forest, never staying anywhere for long). He turns around to face you with his deep violet eyes. His face is dirty but under the grim you can see his handsome features. Not handsome like the man you ran from, but handsome like a man who is honest and fair. " Well I see you've awaken," he says suddenly.

what do you do??

The shadow does as it's told and swiftly goes before you. It is so well camoflauged, that you can barely keep track of it.
You look down and notice you still have a shadow "following" you. You smirk as you think of yourself as the Shadow Master.

You are then encompased by a giant shadow, but this shadow is not attached to anything. It bows before you.

1222121.content:
You understand that you and this dark shadow warlord are kindred spirits. You open your arms and nod, granting him permission to join you. You speak no words, but you seem to understand him, and he you.
The giant shadow rises and steps towards you and into you, posessing you. A dark gleam is in your eye as you feel the immense power within. You are ready for anything.
You go forward, trampling over anything in your path. You are on a mission and determined that nothing will stop you.
But you do pause.....what is that you hear? Boisterous, loud, voices. They are not in view, yet.

choices: See what else you can do to The Shadow
1222122.content:
As The Shadow kneels before you the reality of the situation sinks in. You're alone, unarmed in a forrest. Your pluse quickens and seems to be pounding in your ears. A cold shiver of fear creeps up your spine and encloses it’s fingers around your throat. You step backwards trying to distance yourself from this unnatural shadow creature. You stumble, you fall. Hitting the hard forrest ground you graze your palms. You feel the jolt from the fall and the sting from the minor scrapes. You feel? Oh my... you feel? This is not some horrific deranged dream that you’ll happily wake up from, warm and safe in your bed?

Pannicking you cast your hands around the forrest ground looking for the first make shift weapon that comes to hand. You grasp a fist sized rock and with all your might you hurl it at the dark mass infront of you. You aim is true and the rock sails through the air toward what you’re asuming is the creatures head. Meeting no physical obstruction the rock continues to fall, losing momentum it falls to the ground with a thud. The creature seems unperturbed by your sudden neophyte at tack.

You sit like a rag doll on the cold hard ground. Shocked and a little dazed, you laugh. What else is there to do, save cry? Laughing feels good, it staves off the fear and you breathe in big deep breaths of fresh forrest air. The Shadow lifts his head to look at you and tilts it slightly to the left as if it’s measuring you up or not completely understanding you.

“Ok, shadow buddy. Off to a bad start... i won’t try that again. Scouts honour! You’re not here to hurt me are you? Do you speak?”

The Shadow continues to stare blankly at you. You move onto your knees and crawl cautiously towards it, not trusting your legs to walk just yet. You reach out to touch it and your hand moves through it like smoke. I wonder... you pool your new found shadow powers into your hands and reach out again. This time your hand connects with something solid. You run your hand over the creatures head and it shudders, yet rubs its head harder against your hand like a happy purring cat. You grin delighted and for the first time in a very long time you feel whole. You feel like this is where you belong.
1222122.title: Fighting Shadows

choices: Ignore the voices an start your mission
12221221.content:
The way of the shadow’s had always been your way. Always prefering night time over day. Always prefering winter over summer. Even as a child you weren’t afraid of the dark. You’re ready for this mission. You stand up and brush yourself off. You walk with purpose toward the shadow creature pulling your powers back into. You step into the centre of the creature and allow it to engulf you. You feel calm and centred.

*I wonder*... you draw the shadow creature into you drinking in it’s exquisitte dark power. Your body is humming with confidence and power as you feel the way of the shadow surging through your veins. Your senses are heightened, colours are brighter, sounds are sharper, even your sense of smell is keener. You breathe deeply through your nose taking in the smell of damp musty forrest, the moss, the tree trunks, even the spicy smelling ants. The sweet smell of your heavy cloak, your leather bottons, your cotton shirt. You look around in wonderment. It feels like this is the first time you’ve opened your eyes and seen clearly. You can see everyhting and even better you can see everythings shadow.

You also hear far off voices...
12221221.title: Join with The Shadow

You get on with your journey.

Looking around to get you barings you see the sun glaring down at you from up above you are tempted to cast darkness but decide it would be wise to start on your journey as it will be long and no dubt dangerous.

Which way is west? you think to your self

As you walk the terrain becomes more and more rocky and it becomes increasingly difficult to traverse with each step, but you continue on all the same.

As the sun starts to set you realise you are going in the right direction, but do you continue on or rest here for a while

After you decided to continue on, you reached a massive jagged cliff, luckily your clothes came with gloves, and you new strength gave you confidence to climb up.

You have the choice of drinking the soda river or finding some actual water.

Do you turn back or explore the caverns?

13.content:
"You have made a wise choice."

The wizard raises his wand, and in a flash of light you are transformed. You can feel the difference as new strength and clarity of mind comes to you. A great forest appeares and surrounds you on all sides, with giant trees that would easily compete with the Redwoods.

The wizard smiles and says, "There is one more choice you have to make, and I'm sure it will be an easy one! Would you prefer to be male or female? This will have no bearing on your abilities, but may give you certain advantages or disadvantages in the long run!"
13.title: Gender Smender - Good Elf

choices: You begin your journey to the Rivers of Dan.
You decide to experiment with your new abilities.
131.content:
Immediatley your wish is granted and the wizard says, "Be cautious on your journey. This forest holds powers unknown to you. You have been lightly equipped in your transformation, and before you reach the edge of the forest will have opportunities to increase your skills and gain weapons. Beware of the one called Domarion, for his power is great and he seeks to destroy you."

"Before you go great wizard, I implore you, please tell me more of my mission."

"Alright, but quickly," he says as he draws closer to you.
Continuing in a low voice he shares some more information.
"A great conflict is brewing between the forces of good, which are to the North and South and the forces of evil which are to the East and West. This forest has always been considered neutral ground, and for this moment still is. But soon it will be a bloody battleground."
The wizard pauses with a sorrowful look in his eye, as if he is seeing the future.
"You have been brought here alone and in secret, chosen because of your exceptional abilities - your sharp mind, able body, and strong personality. The fate of the forest and this realm will rest in your hands, and the hands of others just like yourself, who have also been chosen."

"What is causing the conflict?" you ask, still confused.

"I don't have time to go into this now. You will learn as you travel. Be careful who you befriend in this forest. Some can give you invaluable insight and help, and others live only to decieve and destroy you," the wizard informs.

The wizard seems to fade before your eyes, leaving you alone in the forest.
You can hear his voice in the wind saying, "You need to journey to the Rivers of Dan, far to the South. There you will gain perfection in your new craft and complete understanding and direction."
131.title: Mission - Rivers of Dan (M)

1311.content:
You are dressed in Elven clothing, light comfortable and in the colors of the forest. You noticed that you've even been equiped with a bow and a pack of arrows, even though you've never done any archery.
Your pointed ears are sensitive, so much that you can hear an individual leaf hitting the ground. Your hearing range has also improved, and you are hearing high and low pitches that you had not noticed before. There is a constant, deep moaning in this forest that you are very aware of now.
Your sight has also improved and you are able to see much farther and with greater clarity than before. Your periferal vision has increase dramatically, and any movement threatens to distract you.
You notice smells that are new to you. You kneel down seeing the tracks of a deer. You can pick up on the deer's scent!
The most dramatic change is the 6th sense you've gained. You can feel it in your being - the oneness with nature itself. You are connected somehow, in your mind and in your soul. You close your eyes and breathe in the air, feeling the power course through you - the power of nature and all it's glory.

You are guided by the trees that seem to speak to you. Their moanings have melody and reason to them, and you understand their concepts.
The wind whispers secrets of the forest in your ears, and you are growing wiser by the moment.

You keen sense of hearing informs you of vicious hunters. They are still safe distance away, but if their course is not changed, you will encounter them.
1311.title: your course (M)

13111.content:
Not knowing quite why you decide to stay on this path. You stop for a moment and listen to all the forest has to tell you about the party you're about to encounter. Sniffing the air you analyze all the information the wind has brought to you as well. It paints a dire picture of careless, thoughtless, and cruel beast that care naught for anything but their own needs. You've read a few fantasy books in your time, and based on all the information you now have your best guess is you're facing a party of three to four Orcs.

You look to your shoulder and find a pack settled comfortably on your back. Crouching down in some bushes you pull the pack from your back. Not only do you have a full pack, but a 6ft long recurve bow and a quiver of about 20 razor tipped arrows. You deftly string your bow, and pull three arrows like a pro, though you've never handled one before. Somehow it all seems right, and the forest and all it's creatures need to be protected from these perversions of nature that currently roam the forest.
13111.title: Cramming for your first test (M)

choices: Take out the last one first
131111.content:
Though they are probably trying to be quiet, to your new elven ears it sounds like an off key marching band. As of yet they aren't visible, but it won't be long. Surveying the area you determine that they are most likely traveling along a wide game trail off to your left.

You quickly spy a defensable position made by a fallen tree that has a good view of the game trail. Dropping down next to the tree you pull three more arrows from your quiver and plant in the soft dirt by your knee for easy access.

As the Orcs come into view you see that there are actually four of them, and "damn" they're big. Notching an arrow onto the bowstring you decide it would be best to:
131111.title: Protector of the Forest (M)

choices: Stay where you are to see who shares your dislike of Orcs.
1311111.content:
You pull the string back, taking careful aim at the last orc in line. He's dragging his kill behind him - a beautiful whitetail deer. The site fills you with anger that they are marring this forest.
You let go of the arrow as it slices the air landing in the ear of the orc. He lets out a horrific scream as he drops the deer and grabs his head in agony. The other orcs start looking around for their attacker, as you pull back another arrow.
Taking aim, and caution to stay hidden, you fire another shot. This one meant for the leader of the pack. You manage to hit him between the eyes.
The two remaining orcs have picked up on your location. One is running towards you and the other is pulling back on his poison arrow.
You do not have time to run or shoot, and thoughts swirl in your mind on what to do next.
Fortunately, the decision is made for you as the orc drawing his arrow goes down with a thud. The one running towards you is only 6' away with his sword drawn. He falls to the ground, pelted with arrows in his back.
1311111.title: Downsizing (M)

choices: Travel with the Band of Elves.
Strike out due South on your own.
13111111.content:
A thought appears in your head, your not sure what to make of it, it says only
"Friend or foe?" Your Elven brain kicks up a gear, there is wisdom in you and you realize that it must be Woodland Elves that have saved you, but you're still in danger, without an answer to the telepathic message they may very well consider you a foe, and then their arrows will pierce you far more easily that the tough hides of the orcs.
You search your mind for the locked knowledge of how to use your new powers but nothing is forthcoming, 'a real elf would just know' you think to yourself before coming to the logical conclusion, you 'imagine' yourself calling out the word friend, imagine yelling it at the top of your voice, imagine the vibrations moving out in the direction that the Elvish arrows originated. "Not so load friend, every living being in the forest must have heard that." comes the voice in his head and then aloud "O.k you can come out, he's a friend, as you all heard."
The assortment of Woodland Elves moves out from the surrounding undergrowth. there are about twenty fair haired males and females, emerging from all around you. then the leader, the one you were taking to says. "Good 'morrow friend. How come you to this place."
A long conversation follows as to your miraculous transportation and the Elf seems quite interested. "We are on our way South East, we are to scout the domain of the Dark Elves, using the forest as cover for as long as possible and then turning North when we get passed to the end of the miners deep into the heart of the Dark Elves Realm. You are welcome to follow us and learn of Elves and your new self, I think it would be useful to you, and we would be growing closer to our homeland and the Rivers of Dan for some time yet, there is much you should know."
13111111.title: Silently Yelling at the Top of your Voice (M)

131111111.content:
"You have much to learn before we reach the edge of the forest, and time grows short. There is much to do." Says the leader of the Elves aloud.

"I don't know where to begin." you reply, "What would be best, learn of my powers as an Elf, the powers of my mind and the aid of nature? or what of this place, the war, my goal should I ask you of them?"

"Ok Friend, I will decide, perhaps it is best you learn either of your powers first or of the simple techniques and skills that we Elves have to survive."

You begin to ponder over the two possibilities.

"I will give you this advice, though your choice may not be influenced by it. Survival skills are not easily mastered but are quickly learned. The Elvish powers are hard to teach, harder to learn and almost un-masterable. Both could be a great help to you in your journey, but squander the friendship of the forest and of all nature and it will turn on you."
131111111.title: Elvish Ways (M)

choices: You ask to learn their survival skills.
1311111111.content:
Fortunatley you transformation helped in your learning ability so now you can now learn far mcuh faster than you used to.


As you walk down the forest path the Forest Elves talk to you about the Elven lore and How to use your powers. They demonstrate several abilities like making a sprout grow to a giant tree.


And making a stream flow with great torrents. They now give you instructions on how to this and several other things such as controlling and manipulating fire ice, some energy and things like that.


You follow their instructions and you carry out the instructions with ease and have soon done the almost impossible, mastering the powers.
1311111111.title: Elvish Powers

You travel with them for several days. As
you go they show you which berries are safe and
which are poison. They show you how to sleep
safely and how to repair a broken arrow.
They show you a lot of things.

Then the day comes when you must go further
south to the Rivers of Dan and they are not

wizard warned you about.

choices: The footsteps continue until you can't hear them wiTh no signs of Domarian
13111111121.content:
Understanding the dangers associated with him, you realize there is no way you are ready for Domarian. Although you realize that there will be a time and a place for this confrontation, you are certain that if you were to try and confront him now, you would almost certainly perish.

Thinking about the best course of action, you quickly remember what the elves had taught you. The forest is your friend, so why not utilize the forest to help you out. Looking around, you find a tree with lush foliage that will provide an adequate hiding space while you carefully listen. Climbing the tree, you go about half way up, putting yourself about 30 feet off the ground and the. Crouch on the branch focusing all your attention to your ears.

Listening intently, you continue to hear many things, but using your concentration, you are able to focus in on the thud of metal hitting the ground in the rhythm of footsteps. Without needing any help, you are able to figure out that this is Domarian, but since you are new to this, you struggle to identify the direction that he is moving, so you decide the best course of action is to wait.
13111111121.title: Avoid Domarian

choices: Wait for the other two Orcs to return
Go looking for the other two Orcs
1311112.content:
As all four of the evil creatures come into view you see that the last one is dragging a deer carcass behind him by the leg. Strong and Quick enough to catch a full grown buck, you decide that a Four against One showdown might not be the brightest thing to do. Perhaps if you could split them up you could eliminate them easier and safer.

Looking around for some way to distract them you spy a broken limb full of large pine cones swaying in the breeze. A good shot would drop them and make quite a bit of noise. That would get their attention you decide.

Taking a deep, steadying breath you draw back on your bow and take aim. There it is....this should be easy......hold...hold.....Release!! The arrow speeds silintly from your bow and cuts clean through the remaining wood holding the branch in place. As it tumbles into the surrounding brush it makes a loud crash, and the orcs stop dead in their tracks.

The lead orc utters a few gutteral grunts and points back to where the crash occured. All of them are looking back into the brush from where they had just come. The leader's grunts and croaks get louder as the last two orcs pull wicked looking swords and head back into the woods.

Now is my chance you think, as you notch another arrow onto the bowstring. You feel a little queasy aiming at a living thing, but looking at the broken deer laying in the dirt hardens your resolve, and you sight up on the leader. You must hurry before the other two orcs return, and soon the leaders head and neck is all you see past the feathers of your arrow. You release your first shot and have already sighted in on the second orc before the first shot even hits flesh.

The leader makes a loud sqeal as barbed shaft sprouts out of his throat, and blood fountains down the front of his chest. It's not the cleanest kill, but heck it's only your second shot ever. The second Orc is frozen for a second as he looks at his dying leader, and that second is his last as a feathered shaft bisects his head. Looking like a twisted Steve Martin joke gone horribly wrong, he drops to the ground without uttering a sound.

With these two out of the way you decide to:
1311112.title: Bloodied Hands (M)

choices: Stick around and see who else hates orcs.
13111121.content:
You know they’ll be returning soon, and the forest needs to be rid of these vile creatures. You notch up your forth arrow and draw bead on the trail waiting for the two remaining orcs to return. You can hear them crashing around in the distance, but they are steadily getting closer. Taking a deep breath you know it won’t be long now.

With each action in this new body things are get easier and easier. It’s like you’re remembering something you used to do all the time, and now it’s coming all back to you. As you patiently wait, motionless in the undergrowth, you hear and feel the forest all around you like a living creature. You now have no reservations about eliminating these crimes against nature, and you eagerly await their return.

Just then the bushes shake along the trail and a dark brown Orc head erupts through the vegetation. He spy’s his leader bloodied in the dirt, and he begins gibbering and chattering excitedly to the other Orc. Strangely enough you find that you can even understand a word or two, and he seems to believe that they were attacked by the elves that live in these woods. Well you figure, that’ll be the first thing the poor beast got right today. . . and the last. As the second orc plows into the clearing and witnesses the death of their companions they begin scavenging possessions off the bodies and looking nervously between the trees and their dead leader. Gathering up everything they can carry they move away from the area as fast as they are able.

This is even better you figure, because with their arms full they will be slower to respond once you begin shooting. From your vantage point behind the fallen tree you still feel you can make a good shot, even though they have moved a good distance away. Taking a deep breath you draw a bead on one of the orcs that is more in the open than the other. As he leans on a tree catch his balance you release your shot, and your arrow flys unerringly toward its intended target. With a solid thud and a high pitched squeal your shot punches through the orcs forearm, nailing him to the tree. He screams and dances around, but you can see this one ain’t going anywhere for the moment, so you bring your next shot in line with the back of his frightened companion. Just as you are about to release your shot into the back of his neck, you see his body jerk and spasm as three arrows sprout from his hide like porcupine quills. As it falls over dead in the mud you hold your shot, and pause to see what is happening. In less than a heartbeat the orc stapled to the tree is head shot and his bloody carcass slumps over still attached to the tree.

Not knowing what is out there you decide to:
13111121.title: Tidying Up (M)

choices: Go with the elves to their city
131111212.content:
Emerging from brush on all sides of you are elves. They appear from behind trees and slip down the trunks from under the bright green canopy. So quietly do these beings move through the forest that you wonder if it’s actually happening or if you are dreaming. They gather around the bodies of the orcs conversing with disgusted looks on their faces. Finally one of the elves breaks off from the rest of the group and approaches your hiding spot. As it becomes obvious to you that your presence is known to the elves you slowly stand up, and face the one
approaching you.

“Good Morrow my friend”, he begins. “I am Derin, leader of this patrol, and apprentice to Jarad, the Kings Royal Huntmaster. You have a keen eye and a strong arm, and you are welcome in our woods.”

You are startled that you understand everything he says perfectly, then you remember that you are an elf too. “Good Morrow to you sir. I am new to these lands, but could not tolerate the stain those evil creatures left in these beautiful woods of yours. If it would be no imposition to you, I would like to learn something about this area, and what other creatures I may encounter in my travels?”

Derin smiles and pats you on the shoulder. “It is the least I can do for one of my brothers. Shoulder your bow and follow us to Dan’na Dale, our city. There we give you all the help we can.”

You decide to:
131111212.title: Bonding with the natives (M)

choices: Join Derin and the woodland elves in defense...
Wait to see what is going on...
1311112121.content:
As Derin and the other elves lead you to their city, Dan'ne Dale, Derin tells you of his people.
"Long have we been patroling these woods, and many creatures have we met, but lately it seems that we've encountered more orcs in these parts than ever before. Normally we are forced to face the dark elves, but we've found that they have combined forces," Derin informs you.
"But why would dark elves ever want to join the orcs? Don't they hate orcs like us too?" You ask, wondering how you knew that.
"Yes, you are right. It has always been a misconception that since dark elves are evil, they like the orcs. But for as long as I can remember, all elves hate orcs with a passion. Why all of a sudden are the dark elves changing their tune?" Derin replies.
You do not answer him for you realize that you have just entered the elven city, Dan'ne Dale. You cannot believe what is before your eyes, indeed a spell has been cast upon you, for such beauty couldn't possibly exist.
