You frown. "Sometimes, but...."
"See! It's a natural thing to assume different personas in your dreams."
You continue frowning. "Yeah, but...who's to say this is really a dream." You wince and lock your eyes on that shaft sticking out of you. "The pain feels real enough."
The man seems to consider this. "But what else could it be but a dream? I remember going to bed and....boom! I'm talking to that wizard dude." He smiles. "Dream or not. We're bound to find out soon enough.But either way, let's just play it out and see what happens, huh?"
You sigh. "We can't wake up," you reply. "So what other choice do we have?"
The elf nods and pushes off the wall. He locks his hands around the arrow. You wince, but hold in your tears. You couldn't cry in front of another guy! You'd never be able to live that down!
With a snap, the shaft is broke. Only an inch or two sticks from your arm now.
The man steps back to admire his work then nods. "Yeah. That should lighten things for you." He then gathers his stuff from behind a rock and motions for you to follow him. "Let's go. We have to get back to her."
"Who?"
"The girl I met. She is one of us. She needs our help and she can probably help you with that wound."
"Girl?" That word didn't sound too bad at the moment. You push off the rock and follow at the man's heels. The two of you make your way past the bodies of those boars and further across the grassland to a wide river. You stop at the river's edge and gaze out at the far shore. You see nothing out of the ordinary. Just a few bare trees and thin vegetation. But the man seems to think otherwise and cups his hands over his mouth.
"Jenna! I got him!"
The bushes part and out jumps a gray wolf. You frown in disappointment. Is this the girl he spoke of? Really funny.
The wolf pads over to the river's edge and something miraculous happens. The water disappears! Just like that! Almost as if it never was there. You gape in shock. How had....?
The wolf then crosses the dry riverbed and sits down beside you and your comrade. You watch in added shock as the beautiful beast changes into a girl before your eyes!
Red shoulder length hair. Great, green eyes. She has clothes on, you notice. A simple grass stained white dress. Somehow she was able to transform with it.
"Hi," she says with a smile. You find yourself speechless as her white teeth nearly blind you. "I'm Kala. I'm glad you are okay. Me and Turin were worried about you."
"Me? Worried?" The dark elf spits on the ground and walks away to sit by himself.
You make a face as you and Kala stare at his back. "Is that why he left me to fend for myself? Because he was worried for me?"
Kala shakes her red head. You notice the same pointy ears on her as Turin has. "My brother was more worried for my wellbeing after he was taken. I assume he raced off to find me before he even thought to save you."
"Whatever." You dismiss her comment with a wave of the hand and turn away. "But I don't need anyone to 'save me.'"
"But you have no powers to call your own."
"I don't need 'em."
The girl elf laughs. "I don't doubt your decision. You are different than many. Stronger, I'd assume. For you have chosen to come into an unknown world with nothing but your wits." She then sighs. "You are stronger than my brother and I, even."
"I am?" Her answer disarms you and you turn around to see her lowering her head. "But...you're strong too. How else could you have made it past those boar creatures?"
"You mean those woarks?" She shakes her head. "Turin saved us, not me. He allowed himself to be captured while I fled."
"How do you know what your captors were called?"
She looks up at you and winks. "A little birdie told me."
Turin then stalks back to you, a presence more than a substance behind his dark cloak. "We can't stay here. They'll have this whole place filled with hunters by afternoon."
The three of you glance to the east and shield your eyes from the rising bloodred sun. "Where do we go then?"
Turin frowns. "I doubt we should continue through this grassland. We'll be fair game in such flats. So we either head to that forest over there." He gestures across the riverbed to the black wall beyond. "Or we head back to those rocks you and I just came from. I thought I saw a cave somewhere up there."
Kala looks to you. "Your mind is your best weapon, friend. We'll leave this decision up to you."
1512121111211121.title: Why Stay Yourself? That's so Weak!

1512121112.content:
Swiftly, your fellow captive smiles. "I can throw my voice. I will create a distraction. Then you free yourself and then me. I grab my sword, and then I cover getaway."
Two seconds afterwords, from the bushes comes the bugling tragic call of a dying moose.
Your captor's eyes blaze red, and they run to investigate the noises.
You nod approvingly. "That wasn't bad!"
He smiles.
Quickly pulling out your knife, you cut your bonds, noting the jagged knife is a little rusty.
Suddenly, you cut the bonds of your comrade, who silently runs over and grabs his confinscated sword, smiling as he notes its curved blade. He caresses it as if its a lost friend. He hands it to you. Staring at the beautiful weapon, you shake your head. "I couldn't take such a thing! It's too nice."
"Take it!" he hisses. "I'll take it back in a couple of minutes. Slowly, he gets down on the ground on all fours. He opens his mouth, and utters one word. "Runko."
His face changes, and his clothes fall off in a heap. His hands harden into hooves, and his hair turns a milky yellow, his eyes darken. He gets larger, until suddenly, there stands before you a beautiful milky-white steed, a horse with mysterious haunting brown eyes, and with shiny brown hooves. He motions for you to get on. WOndering if it is ethical to ride your friend, you hesitate. Suddenly, you hear ferocious shouting. You see the horrible creatures, crossbows raised, eyes blazing red with fury. Without a moment's hesitation, you mount the beautiful horse. Dodging bolts fired with a terrible fury, the horse sails over their heads. As they curse in a strange language, you smile as you and your comrade gallop off into a glorious crimson sunset.
1512121112.title: Dying Moose Cause Happiness- Old (Nonexistant) Chi

1512122.content:
As the fourth and last creature in the line of monstrosities--the one leading you by your leash--presses forward, you come to a sudden decision. Without regard to the consequences that may stem from your undoubtedly rash actions, you decide to tempt fate and win your freedom.

Quietly and slowly, you take the knot of your rope shackles in your teeth and pull the simple knot apart. In your right hand, you open the knife--good, stainless steel--and twist the crude rope around your left hand twice to get a good grip. As your captor nears the rock formation, you strike--quickly, brutally, and utterly silently, with a ruthless efficiency that startles the small part of your mind that is only now realizing that perhaps remaining exactly as you were may have granted you nothing--but may have left you with powers that you never knew you had.

As the rope of the leash settles around the short, thick neck of the brute in front of you, it stops in dull-witted surprise. As you tighten it into a makeshift - but very effective garotte - it tries to bellow a warning to its companions - in vain. But the monster's trachea is no longer in any condition to allow whispering, let alone bellowing.

As part of the same motion, you drive the wicked steel point of the knife into the monster's back, where instinct tells you is a vital point. Even your killer's mind does not expect what comes next, though: instead of bleeding and dying, quietly, the monster shudders in silent but obviously intolerable pain. The flesh around the knife shrivels, instantly, and sublimates without a sound or smell, into fine gray ash and then, almost instantaneously, into nothing. The dessication proceeds in a matter of seconds throughout the creature's body. Bones and tissue alike are reduced to nonexistence. Not even a smear of blood remains on the knife.

You have learned a valuable lesson, one you would do well to remember in this world of magic, and of unknown and unknowable peril: iron kills. Cold iron is, of course, the most feared by fey creatures, but solid iron of any temperature is bane to all creatures of magic.

The three remaining monstrosities move forward unconcernedly--they have no doubt as to their erstwhile comrade's ability to handle a single puny human, and your deadly attack was carried out with such perfect technique that no sound escaped to alert them. And blood that is sublimated by iron gives off no telltale scent.

All of this took but a few heartbeats, and as the kill is concluded, your calm, machinelike deadliness vanishes, to be replaced by amazement, adrenaline--and fear. You've just killed a monster in cold blood, displaying an inhuman efficiency and an equally monstrous lack of fear or even excitement. In an instant, you are once again a frightened, isolated boy. The dark killer that invaded your mind from within is gone without a trace, leaving you with only memories that belong to someone else and a chance to escape. You are revolted in every part of your being by what you have done, but you are grateful to your killer instinct for saving you from a fate quite possibly worse than an eternity in the terrible, but known and therefore less terrifying hell that humans are familiar with.

Your emotions overpower you and you flee into the blasted landscape, heedless of everything except your need to flee the place where you did murder for the first--but probably not the last time.

Miles ahead of you, as you come to a panting halt, you see a rippling in the air in the desert that may be a mirage, a heat wave, or something far more terrible yet--another unknown danger.

Do you attempt to retrace your steps and return to the forest, or do you attempt to forge ahead farther into the desert? Either way means hours of trudging through broken landscape under the punishing rays of the sun, no water for that long or perhaps longer, and terrors lying in wait under every rock and lurking in every shadow. What is your choice?
1512122.title: The Escape and Transformation

choices: It's too quiet - continue to run.
Relax and get your bearings - they are gone.
15122.content:
You know you will die if these massive, greusome creatures have their way, and no doubt will be tortured in the process from the evil looks on their faces.
You feel your only chance is to make a run for it now. It's a long shot, but just maybe it will work. They are huge, but they look slow, and you think you can outrun them.
Before they can bind your hands, you spy a small opening between the tree and them. They were not expecting you to run, so their reaction time was slowed, but only for a second!
You dart past them, not looking back, putting all your focus and effort into running forward. Never have you spent so much energy into one purpose - your life! You hear something wiz by your head, but you press on, running with all your might and praying for a miracle.
After what seems like eternity you begin to slow....you can no longer hear them following. You stop to listen, weary and out of breath, turn and see no one.
15122.title: the chase (M)

choices: You try to climb down the cliff.
You go back into the forest.
151221.content:
You don't trust the silence and your fear controls you. You continue to run, although you have grown so weary. Your inspiration being that the trees are getting smaller and less dense and you feel that you might be nearing the edge of the forest. Your pace slows as the view ahead unfolds before you.
In the clearing, you realize that this is the end of the forest, but a possible greater challenge awaits. You are standing on a steep cliff that plumets down at least 100 feet from what you can tell, although all you can really see is the tops of trees.
And worse - you have no idea if you are at the North edge of the forest!
151221.title: man on the run (M)

1512211.content:
You decide you have had enough of that forest and the dark creatures in it. You decide the cliffs are less dangerous than the shadows that lurk behind you.
You stand there, surveying the area, looking for a place that is accessible to climb down. You are standing in tall, brown grasses that match height with your knees. The ground is hard and rocky and the cliff looks very unforgiving.

In the distance you see something, flying. As you watch, the bird grows larger and larger as the distance between you closes. You have no fear - it's just a bird.
But as he draws near enough that you can see clearly, you realize this bird is huge. And he's not just any bird - he's an eagle. His talons are massive and his wing span is too large to estimate. It isn't long before you realize he's flying directly towards you! His sharp, peircing eyes are looking at you intently!
You remember the Wizard telling you that you are lightly equipped, and you fumble in your jacket pockets. You feel a knife, about the size of a dagger.
And here you are, faced with another decision! Do you stand your ground and try to fight? You don't know if you are this bird's next meal!
Do you run for cover in the forest? With his great size it's unlikely he'll follow.
1512211.title: This Bird Has Flown (M)

choices: Trust him and let him fly you to the north edge.
15122111.content:
You are tired from your marathon run already and the thought of being chased further, and back the way you came, is not your idea of fun.
You decide to stand your ground. The eagle is large, but you are small and nimble compared to this bird.
As the eagle flies closer, not changing his collision course with you, you draw out the knife in your pocket. The handle is marble, perfectly sized and carved to fit your hand. The press of a button releases the hidden blade made of pure gold. It glistens in the sun, sending out a flash of light. The knife is the size of a dagger, and you know you can do some damage if necessary.
You stand firm and ready for anything. But to your surprise, the eagle slows it's flight, gliding in. He rises up over you, turns, and lands 10 yards to your right. He looks at you, but not with the hungry eyes you thought you saw before. His eyes are sharp, but not angry or mean.
You are at a loss of what to do. You expected an attack, and instead, the eagle is just looking for rest, just as you are.
You withdraw the blade and retire the knife back to your pocket, with a heavy sigh. It is then you are further surprised.

"You have reached the west edge of the forest," the eagle speaks!

Your eyes widen in amazement, wonder and curiosity. You think that perhaps you just imagined this. You are weary and your mind is playing tricks on you.

"This is not your destination. I can take you safely to the north edge of the forest."

You are skeptical. How does this eagle know this about you and how do you know you can trust him?

As if reading your mind, the eagle continues, "Look in your left pocket. There you will find a golden compass. Confirm your direction and set your course."

Sure enough, there inside your left jacket pocket lies a compass. It is encased in gold and attached to a gold chain. You marvel at the eagle's wisdom, but do you trust him?
15122111.title: The Eagle has Landed (M)

choices: Go back in and through the forest.
Stay at the edge of the forest and hike around.
1512212.content:
You decide you are no match for this cliff and the dangers that accompany it. You turn around, gazing back into the forest. You dread what is in there, but you are hoping by keeping your eyes open, you can avoid whatever those things were that you encountered before.
As you walk back into the crowd of towering trees, you feel in your pockets. You remember that the Wizard told you that you would be lightly equipped. He told the truth as you pull from your right pocket a knife. The handle is carved from what seems to be marble, but perfectly sized and grooved for your hand to grip. You press a button and it silently releases a golden blade. The blade is finely crafted and extrememly sharp. The knife is the size of a dagger.

"This would have been useful earlier," you mutter to yourself.

You feel in your left jacket pocket something else. A solid, round object that is cold in your hands. You discover it is a compass, protected in a case of gold. Attached is a chain, long enough to wear around your neck, or attach to your belt loop. You realize you are at the west edge of the forest, not the north.
You stop and think. You could go back into the forest and head in the right direction, take your chances with the natives. You could also follow the edge of the forest around until you are in the correct place. This might be safer.
1512212.title: Your New Discovery (M)

choices: Make your dwelling in the tree.
Risk the journey in the dark.
15122122.content:
You decide that it would be better to face long trek around the edge of the Great Dark Forest than to risk being attacked by any more of those . . . things. You look down at your compass, see the needle point toward the north, and you spin on your heels and start walking in that direction.
After what seemed like a couple of hours, you hear a rather loud growl come out of your stomach. Then you realise that you haven't eaten in--how long has it been? You look to the east and see the sun beginning to set through the massive trunks of the endless trees. In a few more hours, it will be dark. You suddenly feel a small twinge of worry. What other kinds of creatures inhabit this forest? Are they hostile? And what of food?
With these concerns weighing on your mind, you take a seat beneath one of the giant trees nearby and think.
You realise that you must find shelter. You don't suspect that you'll survive very long in this great unknown if you haven't got some kind of barrier between you and whatever things exist out there. You look around, trying to spot any kind of loose timber or a cave of some sort to make your temporary dwelling, but to no avail. Nothing but endless trees all around. . .
You slap your forehead. Trees! Of course! You could climb up into one of the giant trees around you and stay up there for the night. Certainly no one would find you up there, and you are sure that you could climb it. Then again, you don't know what might live in the trees. And then there's the matter of food.
You consider traveling through the night, then. You could follow the edge of the forest by moonlight, and you don't think that you'd lose your way; the sky is cloudless. You may even chance upon some wild berries, or even find a small cave in which to spend the night. But what about the creatures that may come out at night, hungry and eager to prey upon fresh meat?
You look toward the sun again. You don't have more than a few hours left. What should you do?
15122122.title: The Road Gets Rougher

choices: Do you listen to the story
151222.content:
You stop to catch your breath.

It's quiet.

Which is strange since you are in a forest. No a cricket noise, nor a bird chirping. Fear beings to grip you, and you can't shake it off.

You walk for a bit when you notice a small man murmruing to himself. The short stocky bald man, dressed in green stockings, kept murmuring as he eyed you supiciously.

"Jealousy...jealousy...jealousy..."

He turns his beady opal eyes to you and laughs hysterically.

"YOU ! Now that I didn't expect to see!!!!"

"I am sorry...I must keep..."

"KEEP. yes with WHAT. You have no powers, what fool choses him self...."

He falls to ground laughing in extreme glee.

Annoyed you try to look menacing.

"O LORD! He's looking at me , please do NOT pierce ME with your LOOK."

Now incensed you trod off, huffing and puffing , trying not to hear the buffon's laughter. You think you lost him, until you turn around to find him right behind you.

"Would you like to hear a story?"

You look at him like he's insane.

Which he probably is?
151222.title: Story Time

choices: RUN; They could be after you
What is this about , you wonder?
1512221.content:
"FINE! Tell me the damn story!"

The buffon sits down cross legged, and adobts a deep low voice.

"Once there were many beasts, and God looked to them and said I have created you, but do you wish for any boon to aid you in this life.

The dog came to him and said give me a snout to help me find food.


The lion came to him and said give me razor sharp teeth so that I may be able to kill my prey.


The bird came to him and said give me wings so that I may fly above my enemies.

And so each animal came up to God and their wish was granted.

All except man.

When it came to man, he said only, "O Lord, you have created me in your light. I will stay the way you wish me to be."

God smiled and said, "See all my children, here stands the greatest one of all. Man you will have nothing to work with. Ill-suited for this life, you will have to depend on your intelligence. With that you will be the lord of all on earth."

You say nothing transfixed by this story.

"See my friend. You chose to be you. Hence you will have a great disadvantage. Ogres, witches, mages will have blades ,spells and magic. However use your own innate abilities and you will be all powerful...."

With that the buffon rose up and slowly walked away, muttering to himself once more.

Dazed you look around you, and once again you hear the chirpings around you, the crickets, and a clatter of horse feet....

HORSE FEET!
1512221.title: Stories galore

15122211.content:
You turn to run, but instead bang into another taller person. Both of you land on the ground with an oof When you regain your bearings, you look around. The old man is gone, and the horses are getting closer, but now you have something new to deal with.

Lying in front of you is a girl about your age. Groaning and moaning, she looks across at you with a hand planted deftly against her head. She was beautiful. With the form of a dancer, she wore a green dress with slits down either sides of her legs. Two rapiers were strapped to her back, along with an elegant long bow and quiver. The most peculiar thing about her though, were her pointed ears and silted eyes, like a cat. You knew at once she had to be an Elf.

When she looked at you, she was about to ask something when the horse sounds became accompanied by war cries. She growled, her face contorting into a mean frown. Quickly, she grabs a hold of your hand. "Follow me."

The two of you dash off. She leads you into a thick brush and forces you to squat down. You hear her whispering a chant under her breath, but you don't pay any mind. Soon, the horses come galloping up and stop.

"I could have sworn I saw him go this way." It was a thick, harsh voice that spoke.

"The master will have your hide for this. You know the rules. We are not allowed in the inner forests. It's neutral territory!"

There was a loud growl and a bark of a snap. "Let's go. He couldn't have gotten far." The horses galloped away, fading like a distant memory.

When the coast is clear, the girl pushes you out of the brush. "You are the dumbest human I think I have ever met. Don't you know those Goblins would have eaten you without a second thought?"

"Who are you?" was all you could force out.

The girl rolls her eyes, giving you an exasperated look.

"My name is Kesla. I'm a ferester here in the southern reaches. Now, are you lost? If so I know the forest well, and I can also teach you some important survival skills. But I expect your full trust. I'll need to know what you are doing here and where you are headed."
15122211.title: A new friend

choices: "It's getting dark, a warm hutt's better than the cold ground..."
15122212.content:
From between two large trees bursts a rider on a brown horse. She is lightly garbed and carries a single long, curving, blade at her side. Before you can react she leaps from her horse, who trots to a stop a few feet away, and comes to a halt before you. Upon her face is a look of utter confusion.

"What are you doing here?!?!" She shouts.

With a closer look you see that her features are not entirely like anything you've ever seen before. Her eyes are almond shaped and are the most captivating color of green. Her hair, tied back in a single braid, is deep black streaked with shimmering strands of the purest silver. She would be nearly your height if not for her long pointed ears that rise a few inches above the top of her head.

After a moment, during which she waits for your response, you realize that you've been staring at her with your mouth open - entranced by her beauty. Shutting your mouth you stammer out an incoherent answer.

"What?!?" She says, eying you suspiciously.

"I said, 'I'm not sure what I'm doing here."

"No, not HERE," she says, motioning around this particular area of forest, "Why aren't you going north? You were told to journey North, you've gone East!"

You can see she is not happy about this at all.

"I..." you begin to speak, but are suddenly interrupted.

"Don't speak! You're wasting time! You've chosen to be yourself, and that is admirable, I'm sure they'll think highly of..."

"Who'll think highly?"

"Shut up!" she shouts again. "You've chosen yourself, but that also means you've chosen to be unarmed and unprotected. I have been sent to give you this..."

She fumbles quickly with the sheathed sword dangling at her side and, when losened from her belt, she places it in your hands. It is incredibly light and yet it has a feeling of amazing rigidity. Its blade, a wickedly curving thing, is engraved with thousands of designs and symbols and it's handle is bound tightly with a dark brown leather which appears to have been worn smooth by countless years of skilled usage.

"Take it, I have no doubt you'll find use for it before you reach your goal. Now, go! North!"

"Egella!" She calls as she turns towards her horse. The magnificent beast trots over to stand beside her. Tossing a leg over the horses bare back she mounts with a skill you've never seen.

"Wait!" You call before she can go, "Which way is North?"

"I have no time to wait, Check your clothes - you've no doubt been equiped."

And with that she is off, leaving only the sounds of hoofbeats heading West. You search your person and find in your left jacket pocket a lump of some soft sweet bread. In a pouch attatched to your best is a compass made of gold and inlaid with silver symbols similar to those on the sword.

Finding North you begin to trudge through the forest. After a few hours walking you come into a clearing in the center of which sits a small stone hutt. The smoke issuing from the stone chimney tells you someone is home.
15122212.title: Elven Rider

choices: Tell him you're looking for answers.
You fabricate a story of your own.
151222122.content:
Aside from the fact that it is in the middle of a strange and apparently quite dangerous forest, the hut seems like a good place to perhaps learn more about whatever your "goal" might be--you are, after all, now armed, so at least you have a fighting chance should things go wrong.

Entering the clearing, you begin to hear some kind of strange noise coming from within the hut. A bit startled, you glance around the clearing for somewhere to hide. Nothing. Not wanting to waste time, you cautiously dash across the clearing and press your back up against the hut. It seemed only an hour earlier you had barely awaken from...something, and already had been given your fair share of surprises; you were not about to be taken by surprise again, especially now that you carried a long, sharp and ornately decorated sword--something of obvious specialty.

You realize that the noise was laughter--male, human, fairly old--and that it is growing by the minute. Within seconds it escalates into a wildly hysterical roar, and you begin to worry when, without notice, the thatch front door bursts open.

An elderly old man appears, half crawling, half stammering, his worn wrinkly face made even more wrinkly by the sheer level of laughter erupting not only out of his mouth by, from what you can tell, his entire body.

Crazy old kook.

As if he could read your thoughts, he immediately stops, turns, eyes your sheath, and looks you in the eye and screams, "WHO RE YOU!?"
151222122.title: The Crazy Old Kook

choices: You say you need some time to think it over.
You're sorry for intruding and you'll be leaving now (and fast!)
1512221221.content:
You tell the crazy old kook the first thing that comes to your bewildered mind.

"I, uh...lost," you manage to say.

"Is that so?" he replies, his voice now much deeper, almost too deep for his age.

"Yes, it is, actually," you respond, "but I'm here for answers, if you have any. Please, if I may, tell me: where am I?"

"One does not simply make inquiry of me, little lost boy. One only listens as I speak FIRST--" He pauses, looking you hard in the eye. You cannot tell whether or not you catch a change in his eyes, but you suddenly feel a subtle chill run through your bones. "SECOND, they shall obey, and only then third may I answer one's inquiries."

"Listen," you reply, "I've had a long--"

He cuts you off, speaking in such a low tone, hardly audible, that you now question whether or not he is even human. "Answer me this, little lost boy, or you may never again feel life on earth as you feel it in you now. Will you kill the red-wooded tree, OR..." He pauses, uneasily shifting his weight, but not his age-recessed eyes' firm stare into your own. "...will you kill the blue-wooded tree?"

It's a riddle, for sure, but what do you do now?
1512221221.title: One Only Listens

15122212211.content:
"I don't know what you are talking about--a red-wooded tree? A blue-wooded tree?" You realize now that smoke is beginning to drift (or is it being pulled?) out of the hut, slowly but eerily encompassing the old man, who is beginning to look more and more ghostly by the minute. You boldly continue speaking. "Without any knowledge of such things, which I am indeed without, how can I possibly make my decision?"

"With force," the old man simply replies, and a moment later the smoke begins drifting toward you as if it had a life of its own. "So tell me, for the last time, will you kill the red-wooded tree, or will you kill the blue-wooded tree?"

It appears you are out of options.
15122212211.title: Out of Options

151222122111.content:
"It is done, then," the old man replies.

You can't help but notice an unusual, metallic glint appear in his eyes, reflecting the unsettling haziness of the dark smoke still approaching you.

A small faerie-like creature suddenly appears floating beside the man's head, sparkling an array of fierce reds and oranges in a sort of angelic, halo-like fashion.

"Follow the lokin," the kook commands, "and he will lead you to the tree which you must destroy." The old man then turns and, without another word, disappears back into the smoky hut. As he does so the ghostly smoke slowly recedes back beneath the shut door, and you become abruptly aware that it's now a whole lot easier to breathe.

The lokin wastes no time in leading you on into the setting sun.

"So, ah...where exactly are we going?" You ask, hoping it might speak some form of English.

No reply, just more flashing and blinking of sparkly lights, which, now that you think about it--no, now that you feel it--you feel relaxed and at ease, almost comforted.

You make another stab at conversation. "Is this tree far?"

Still no reply.

You notice you're heading in somewhat of an east or northeasterly direction, and also that the trees begin to thin. Thoughts begin playing in your head. What if I don't want to do this? What'll the little pixie-thing do to me, anyway? Well, this is a strange forest. Best to at least follow it, if it won't talk.
You begin to wonder whether the task may be as simple as you first thought. What does it mean to kill a tree, anyway? Cuting it down is the first thing that comes to mind; the elvish sword is, afterall, rather lightweight but feels sharp enough to displace a smaller tree. But it was some kind of riddle, so maybe you won't be cutting down a tree.

What am I even doinghere? you ask yourself, only to realize a second later you voiced it aloud.

The 'lokin' creature presses on, floating vibrantly but silently. You begin wondering if its brightness may not serve in your best interests come nightfall...who knows what other strange things might befall you before days end?
First there was the pursuit, then the first crazy man, then the elvish girl who at least reaffirmed some of the wizard's words, then the second crazy man, and now--

Your thoughts come to a halt as the dark forest also does, revealing to you a vast wasteland that stretches as far as you sight can reach into the coming black of night. Something catches your eye and you look harder, and you notice that there is a blackish fog floating far off in the east, slowly pouring down into a dry riverbed that follows a wide valley into the forest further south.

To the north you see the forest line fade into what appears a wall of rock, but at closer inspection you make out as a large and rugged mountain range, the lofty tips catching the last red rays of the setting sun. They remind you of those fire beacons in that Lord of the Rings movie.

"What is this place?" You ask the lokin, now paused.

There is a quick rustling sound behind you, and before you can blink a red, branch-like appendage descends around your waste and hoists you up. Straining agianst the iron grip you turn and face this menace and are surprised to find that you are being lifted by the branch of a red-wooded tree!

You take this quick chance to try your luck with the sword, only to have another of the tree's branches whip out and snatch it. The tree hoists you higher until it sets you down high atop its apex, where, sitting on a branch and to your utter surprise, you find the crazy old kook.

"Welcome," he says, smiling.

Another surprise.

"You see my strange friend, the colors, they are no significant matter. What matters is that they told me you would chose this path, and, indeed, so you have."

You stare, stunned speechless. The tree branch sets you down atop a branch neighboring his, and then descends back down, rustling noisily as it goes.

"I can understand if you feel powerless, even directionless," he says, "despite all the planning that has gone into this."

"Into what?" you ask, neglecting his first, second, third pecking order.

"Why, of bringing you here, to this world, of course!" he gleefully replies, smoothly spreading his arms out wide, gesturing out across the forest. His change in demeanor from earlier is disarming.

"Please, sir," you beg, "can you tell me what exactly is going on, where I am, am I dreaming, where I am even going?

"You, my stranger from a distant land, are neglecting my order."

"What--!"

The geezer fails to control a rather loud chuckle. "I am only kidding, kidding you see...and I apologize. I will tell you what I know, and then you must go, for things are growing dimmer by the minute."

So his tale begins.
151222122111.title: The Surprises Keep Coming!

151222122112.content:
"It is done, then," the old man replies.

You can't help but notice an eerie glint appear in his eyes, reflecting the unsettling haziness of the dark smoke still approaching you.

A small faerie-like creature suddenly appears floating beside the man's head, sparkling an array of tainted reds and oranges in a sort of angelic, halo-like fashion.

"Follow the lokin," the kook commands, "and he will lead you to the tree which you must destroy." The old man then turns and, without another word, disappears back into the smoky hut. As he does so the ghostly smoke slowly recedes back beneath the shut door, and you become abruptly aware that it's not a whole lot easier to breathe.

The lokin wastes no time in leading you on into the setting sun.

"So, ah...where exactly are we going?" You ask, hoping it might speak some form of English.

No reply, just more flashing and blinking of sparkly lights, which, now that you think about it, don't necessarily make one feel too happy about looking at them. As a matter of fact, they're alarming to you. "Is this tree far?"

Still no reply.

You notice you're heading in somewhat of an east or northeasterly direction, and also that the trees begin to thin. Thoughts begin playing in your head. What if I don't want to do this? What'll the little pixie-thing do to me, anyway? Well, this is a strange forest. Best to at least follow it, if it won't talk.
You begin to wonder whether the task may be as simple as you first thought. What does it mean to kill a tree anyway? Cut it down is your first impression, but for some strange reason you don't think that is what he meant.

Your question, however, is soon answered.

Te trees suddenly give way to a bare wasteland.
In the widening valley further northeast you can vaguely trace a dry riverbed in the dimming dusk.
Gazing around you can see that the night is quickly consuming the sky from the east.

But something does not feel right, and just when you begin to feel your skin tingle you see red branch-like membranes fall before your eyes, and then a very sharp pain from...somewhere...above...then...

Nothing.

Good morning! Bad dream or what? Better chose better next time! IF there is a next time...

Turning to ask the faerie, she is also gone, and the forest is turning strangely dark. The limbs of the trees grow crooked and low, grabbing at you. Screeches of birds violate your ears and a pressure builds around your body. Your head begins to throb, beads of sweat form on your brow, you feel suffocated.

Then suddenly, as quick as it happened, it went away and things went back to normal.

"What was that?" you ask out loud.

"They are looking for you."

Turning you see the boy. "Those faeries are spies, and you have now released one. They'll find you. You have aligned yourself with light. The dark ones will seek you out, for they know your potential."

"And what else do you know of this? Who do you pledge your allegiance to?"

The boy smiles, "The light of course, or you would be dead."

"But what of the story the fearie told of your sister dying?"

"She made it up so you would trust her. They will do all to gain your trust, then turn and decieve you when you least expect it."

"How do I know I can trust you?"

The boy smirked and thought for a moment. "Well, trust is a personal decision that you'll have to make. As you can see, I am not armed, and I have not tried to harm you. Whether you trust me or not, one thing is certain: if you stay here you will be found. You must make haste and go."

You look back up in the tree and see the bird you had been following was no longer there.

"That bird was leading you astray. They are coming for you. They know your location."

Fear starts to build inside as you search for answers.
"What do I do?"

"Leave!"
